docs.lead_paragraph: Let me start with the bottom line: the pain and fever reliever acetaminophen, popularly called Tylenol, its first over-the-counter trade name, is a very safe drug for children as well as for adults. But as with any medication, the dose makes the poison. And with acetaminophen, which has properly replaced aspirin as the drug most often given to infants and children, there is a relatively small window of safety. In infants and small children, studies have indicated that the toxic dose is less than twice the recommended dose. Studies have also shown that it is very easy to mistakenly give children too much acetaminophen and, as a result, endanger their lives and health.

headline.main: With Tylenol and Children, Overdosing Is Perilously Easy

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on risk of overdosing children on acetaminophen, or Tylenol; studies show how easy it is to give children too much Tylenol, endangering their health; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Canada's government has scored a global publicity coup by proposing the world's largest and most graphic cigarette warnings: printing full-color photos of cancerous lungs and lips on cigarette packs. News of the proposal was broadcast around the world last week. But more quietly, Canada's provinces, far from the spotlight, were putting into effect new tactics of their own.

headline.main: Even Quebec Gets Tough on Smoking

docs.abstract: Quebec province imposes its first smoking segregation rules, shaking off a longstanding laissez-faire attitude on smoking; Quebecers smoke more heavily than other Canadians, and Quebec City and Montreal have Canada's highest male death rates from lung cancer; British Columbia is imposing new smoking rules that are possibly the strictest in North America; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Canada's government has scored a global publicity coup by proposing the world's largest and most graphic cigarette warnings: printing full-color photos of cancerous lungs and lips on cigarette packs.    News of the proposal was broadcast around the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers at the University of Massachusetts Medical School have taken immature cells from the spinal cords of adult rats, induced them to grow and then implanted them in the gap of the severed spinal cords of paralyzed rats. Within two weeks, the paralyzed animals began to move, the scientists say, and within three months several of them could stand and walk. The experiment is one of several at laboratories around the world that researchers say provide increased evidence that, with still much more research to come, they will be able to conquer one of the oldest problems in medicine: treating people permanently paralyzed as a result of severed, crushed or diseased spinal cords.

headline.main: Rat Studies Raise Hope Of Conquering Paralysis

docs.abstract: Researchers at University of Massachusetts Medical School take immature cells from spinal cords of adult rats, induce them to grow and then implant them in gap of severed spinal cords of paralyzed rats; scientists say that within two weeks, paralyzed animals began to move, and within three months several of them could stand and walk; experiment is one of several at laboratories around world that researchers say provide increased evidence that they will eventually be able to treat people permanently paralyzed as result of severed, crushed or diseased spinal cords; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Watch the sodas and do not eat the chicken skin, but if you feel like having a glass of wine, or two, help yourself. If the latest revisions to federal dietary guidelines are included in the final version later this month, that advice would be part of the government's basic message.

headline.main: Diet Panel Mixes Politics and Chicken Fat

docs.abstract: Departments of Health and Human Services and Agriculture issue their working draft of fifth edition of Dietary Guidelines for Good Health; three of its first four guidelines have nothing to do with food choices but instead deal with food safety, exercise and weight, all noncontroversial topics (M)
